figure_1: PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) flow diagram illustrating the process of study selection for a systematic review on the effectiveness of social media for dissemination of research evidence for health and social care practitioners, detailing a total of 6451 records identified (5896 excluded), 555 full-text reports screened (505 excluded), and 50 articles included.
figure_2: Meta-analyses of within-group effects after social media interventions on reach in (A) the number of practitioners and (B) impressions or post views.
figure_3: Meta-analyses of within-group effects after social media interventions on engagement in (A) positive responses (likes) and (B) post interactions (total interactions, shares [retweets], comments [replies], or other post interactions).
figure_4: Meta-analyses of between-group effects of social media compared to no social media on direct dissemination in (A) link clicks and article views, (B) article downloads, and (C) the altmetric attention score.
figure_5: Meta-analyses of within-group effects after social media interventions on direct dissemination in (A) link clicks or article views, (B) article downloads, and (C) the altmetric attention score.
figure_6: Meta-analysis of the between-group effect of social media interventions compared to no social media interventions on impact in (A) citations and (B) thinking and practice.
figure_7: Meta-analysis of within-group effect after social media interventions on thinking and practice.
